articles.title: Press release - New EU driving licence rules: press conference on Tuesday at 14.00
articles.summary: Parliament rapporteurs Jutta Paulus (Greens, DE) and Matteo Ricci (S&D, IT) will brief journalists on the EU’s new driving licence rules, shortly after the vote in plenary.Committee on Transport and Tourism Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
On Tuesday at noon, MEPs are expected to confirm an update to EU driving licence rules as well as changes to ensure the disqualification of foreign reckless drivers. With almost 20,000 lives lost on EU roads annually, Parliament wants to make sure the rules help to make roads safer.

The new rules bring in additional requirements for learner drivers, who will have to know about blind spot and phone usage risks and be more aware of pedestrians, children, cyclists and other vulnerable road users. Other innovations include: a new digital driving licence accessible via a smartphone; a probationary period of at least two years for new drivers; accompanied driving for 17-year-olds; and the possibility to obtain a professional truck driving licence from the age of 18, and a bus driving licence from the age of 21.

In addition, a driving licence withdrawal, suspension or restriction abroad will have to be communicated to the EU country that issued the driving licence in order to enforce the penalty and make sure it is effectively applied cross-border.





When: Tuesday 21 October 2025, 14.00 CET

Where: European Parliament in Strasbourg, Daphne Caruana Galizia press conference room (WEISS N -1/201)

Who: Parliament’s rapporteur on driving licence rules Jutta Paulus (Greens, DE) and rapporteur on driving disqualification rules Matteo Ricci (S&D, IT).

How: Accredited media representatives are invited to attend the press conference in person. In addition, journalists can join the press conference and ask questions remotely via the Interactio platform. When connecting, enter your name and the media organisation you are representing in the first name/last name fields. For better sound quality, use headphones and a microphone. Interpretation is only possible for interventions with video.

Interpretation will be available into and from English, French, German, Spanish, Italian and Polish.

The press conference will also be webstreamed live on the Parliament’s Multimedia Centre website. You can follow it here.





Background

The revised EU driving licence rules are part of a road safety package presented by the Commission in March 2023, which aims to improve safety for all road users and to move as close as possible to zero fatalities in EU road transport by 2050 ("Vision Zero").
articles.reasoning: The article reports on new EU driving licence rules aimed at significantly improving road safety across the EU, potentially saving thousands of lives annually. The rules introduce meaningful changes such as enhanced learner driver education, digital licences, probationary periods, and cross-border enforcement of penalties. These measures have broad societal impact and clear positive real-world benefits for public safety and vulnerable road users.
articles.personality_title: EU introduces new driving licence rules to improve road safety
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Every year, nearly 20,000 people lose their lives on roads across the European Union. To reduce accidents and protect all road users, the EU has been working on updating its driving licence rules.

**What happened** – On October 21, 2025, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) approved new rules for driving licences. These changes include extra training for learner drivers about blind spots, phone use, and watching out for pedestrians, children, and cyclists. New drivers will have a probation period of at least two years. Seventeen-year-olds can now drive with someone accompanying them. The rules also allow people to get a professional truck licence from age 18 and a bus licence from age 21. A new digital driving licence will be available on smartphones. Importantly, if a driver’s licence is taken away or suspended in one EU country, other countries will be informed to enforce the penalty.

**Impact** – These rules are important because they address key causes of accidents, such as distracted driving and lack of experience. The digital licence makes it easier to carry and check licences. Cross-border communication about penalties will stop dangerous drivers from avoiding consequences by moving to another country. Overall, these changes aim to save lives and protect vulnerable road users like children and cyclists.

**What's next step** – The new rules will start to be put into practice across all EU countries. Authorities will work on setting up the digital licences and systems for sharing penalty information between countries. Training programs for learner drivers will be updated to include the new requirements. Over time, these actions should help reduce accidents and road deaths.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s updated driving licence rules introduce better training, digital licences, and stronger penalty enforcement to make roads safer for everyone.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE adopte de nouvelles règles de permis de conduire pour renforcer la sécurité routière
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Chaque année, près de 20 000 personnes perdent la vie sur les routes de l’Union européenne. Pour réduire les accidents et protéger tous les usagers, l’UE a travaillé à la mise à jour des règles du permis de conduire.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 21 octobre 2025, les députés européens ont approuvé de nouvelles règles pour les permis de conduire. Ces changements comprennent une formation supplémentaire pour les apprentis conducteurs sur les angles morts, l’utilisation du téléphone et la vigilance envers les piétons, les enfants et les cyclistes. Les nouveaux conducteurs auront une période probatoire d’au moins deux ans. Les jeunes de 17 ans pourront conduire accompagnés. Il sera possible d’obtenir un permis professionnel poids lourd dès 18 ans et un permis de bus dès 21 ans. Un nouveau permis de conduire numérique sera accessible sur smartphone. Enfin, si un permis est retiré ou suspendu dans un pays, les autres pays de l’UE seront informés pour appliquer la sanction.

**Impact** – Ces règles sont importantes car elles ciblent des causes majeures d’accidents comme la distraction au volant et le manque d’expérience. Le permis numérique facilite son port et son contrôle. La communication entre pays empêche les conducteurs dangereux d’échapper aux sanctions en changeant de pays. Ces mesures visent à sauver des vies et protéger les usagers vulnérables comme les enfants et les cyclistes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les nouvelles règles seront progressivement mises en œuvre dans tous les pays de l’UE. Les autorités mettront en place les permis numériques et les systèmes d’échange d’informations sur les sanctions. Les programmes de formation des apprentis seront adaptés. Ces actions devraient réduire les accidents et les morts sur la route.

**Phrase clé** – Les nouvelles règles de permis de conduire de l’UE offrent une meilleure formation, des permis numériques et un renforcement de l’application des sanctions pour rendre les routes plus sûres.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE introduce nuevas normas de permiso de conducir para mejorar la seguridad vial
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cada año, casi 20,000 personas mueren en las carreteras de la Unión Europea. Para reducir accidentes y proteger a todos los usuarios, la UE ha trabajado en actualizar las reglas del permiso de conducir.

**Qué pasó** – El 21 de octubre de 2025, los diputados del Parlamento Europeo aprobaron nuevas normas para los permisos de conducir. Estos cambios incluyen formación extra para conductores aprendices sobre puntos ciegos, uso del teléfono y cuidado con peatones, niños y ciclistas. Los conductores nuevos tendrán un periodo de prueba de al menos dos años. Los jóvenes de 17 años podrán conducir acompañados. Se podrá obtener el permiso profesional de camión desde los 18 años y el de autobús desde los 21. Habrá un nuevo permiso digital accesible en el teléfono móvil. Además, si un permiso es retirado o suspendido en un país, los demás países de la UE serán informados para aplicar la sanción.

**Impacto** – Estas reglas son importantes porque abordan causas comunes de accidentes, como la distracción y la falta de experiencia. El permiso digital facilita llevar y comprobar el permiso. La comunicación entre países evitará que conductores peligrosos evadan sanciones cambiando de país. En conjunto, estas medidas buscan salvar vidas y proteger a usuarios vulnerables como niños y ciclistas.

**Próximo paso** – Las nuevas reglas se implementarán en todos los países de la UE. Las autoridades prepararán el permiso digital y los sistemas para compartir información sobre sanciones. Los programas de formación para aprendices se actualizarán. Con el tiempo, estas acciones ayudarán a reducir accidentes y muertes en las carreteras.

**Frase clave** – Las nuevas normas de la UE para permisos de conducir ofrecen mejor formación, permisos digitales y mayor control de sanciones para hacer las carreteras más seguras.

articles.title: Central African Republic: ‘3R’ combatants in the northwest lay down their arms
articles.summary: As the disarmament team approached, combatants from the Retour, Réclamation et Réhabilitation (3R) armed group stood in two orderly lines expectantly, youthful faces and greying heads alike.
articles.content:
Some carried weapons of war; others ammunition – the very items on which their eligibility for the disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration (DDR) process they were about to embark on depended.

Well-wishes rang out from the small crowd of locals gathered in Sanguere-Lim, Koui Sub-Prefecture, to see the combatants off as they walked from the 3R assembly point towards the nearby makeshift disarmament site being set up by the national unit overseeing and implementing the process.

Music also played out – part of the Government awareness campaign – as a song blared from loudspeakers calling on Central Africans to lay down their arms “in order to go to school, to cultivate the fields or for any kind of livelihood, lay down your weapons, for peace”.

Ongoing operations

The disarmament and demobilisation initiative in Sanguere-Lim marked the latest in a series of ongoing operations launched in July.

They followed a landmark peace agreement between the Government and the 3R and another armed group Unité pour la Paix en Centrafrique (UPC) – signed in N’Djamena, Chad, in April – marking their return to the peace process in the CAR.

The UN peacekeeping mission in the country, MINUSCA, supports the DDR operations, in line with its mandate. The Government launched the national programme in December 2018, and MINUSCA has been providing extensive financial, logistical, technical and security ever since.

MINUSCA/Leonel Grothe The UN peacekeeping force in the Central African Republic is supporting the disarmament and demobilization of members of armed groups.

Looking forward to a new life

Abel Delatid, 25, who joined the 3R in 2017, was among the combatants being disarmed. “I heard about the peace agreement in N’Djamena through awareness-raising by MINUSCA and local authorities. I am looking forward to vocational training to start a new life as I lost my leg during fighting,” he said after surrendering his weapon.

A few obligatory stops awaited the combatants, including handover of weapons or ammunition, a body search, and registration and receipt of a disarmament certificate.

They also receive a medical check-up, choice of vocational training, a special allowance, and starter kit to help with the new road ahead.

Ambition to join the army

For his part, Aroun Isa Oumar expressed a desire to leave behind the tough years spent in the bush.

He hoped to receive training in order to join the national army – a recurrent wish among many combatants – perhaps driven by a lack of information about available programmes supporting reintegration.

Time and time again, Awareness Campaign Officer, Jean Christophe Namyona, briefed ex-combatants stopping at his desk to opt for a preferred vocational training or income-generating activity of their choice – such as commerce, husbandry or carpentry – should they not be eligible for military service.

Disarmament and demobilization operations are guided by a 2016 National DDR Strategy, which outlines specific eligibility criteria.

For example, ex-combatants seeking to join the army must be between 18 and 25.

Eligibility further depends on owning a functional or reparable weapon, or the surrender of 200 rounds of ammunition, eight grenades, or 10 rockets.

Among the combatants previously disarmed in the area was Mbekaka Ursula Aicha, a 29-year-old mother of two and the only female ex-combatant to join the DDR process there.

‘Peace is possible’

She had joined the 3R movement three years earlier, driven by a sense of protest against what she described as the marginalisation of her community.

“I agreed to disarm following the call by the President to return to the country and work for peace, as well as in accordance with orders from the 3R leadership. Now that we have laid down our weapons, peace is possible,” she said.

The Sub-Prefect of Koui, Larry Nordine Mahalba, stressed the importance of disarmament and demobilization and commended MINUSCA’s support.

“For five years, the 3R occupied this region. MINUSCA has supported us on multiple levels – bringing relief to a traumatized population.

Wilfried Relwende Sawadogo, Coordination Officer with the UN Mission, noted that “crucially, disarmament and demobilization operations contribute to pacifying communities, thereby advancing the key MINUSCA mandated task to protect civilians.”

For Sanguere-Lim resident Adama Yaouba, life has turned a corner thanks to disarmament in the locality. “Today, armed groups have laid down their arms, and everything has changed. Before, we never slept peacefully; we lived in constant fear, always on edge. But now, I can sleep calmly, free from worry.”

The 3R Political Coordinator, Yaya Amadou, himself disarmed during previous operations, encouraged others to follow suit.

“The time for war is over, and now is the time to make peace,” he said.

articles.personality_title: Combatants in Central African Republic lay down arms to start new lives
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Central African Republic (CAR) has been affected by armed groups fighting in different regions. Recently, a peace agreement was signed between the government and two groups, including the Retour, Réclamation et Réhabilitation (3R) group, to bring an end to violence and start disarmament and reintegration efforts.

**What happened** – In the northwest town of Sanguere-Lim, combatants from the 3R group lined up to hand over their weapons and ammunition as part of a disarmament, demobilization, and reintegration (DDR) process. The event was supported by the United Nations peacekeeping mission, MINUSCA, and the government. Music and well-wishes encouraged the fighters to embrace peace and new opportunities like schooling and farming. Those disarming will receive medical checks, vocational training options, and starter kits to help build new lives.

**Impact** – This disarmament marks a big change for a region long affected by conflict. People like Abel Delatid, a former fighter who lost a leg in the fighting, now look forward to learning new skills and leaving violence behind. The community feels safer, as one resident said they can finally sleep peacefully. The process also offers fighters choices, such as joining the national army or learning trades like carpentry or farming, depending on their eligibility.

**What's next step** – The DDR program will continue to support more combatants as they lay down arms and reintegrate into society. Local and international groups will keep working together to help ensure lasting peace and provide training and support for former fighters to build stable futures.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Former fighters in the Central African Republic are surrendering weapons and receiving support to build peaceful new lives, bringing hope to a conflict-affected region.

articles.personality_title_es: Combatientes en República Centroafricana entregan armas para comenzar nuevas vidas
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La República Centroafricana (RCA) ha sufrido conflictos con grupos armados en varias regiones. La comunidad se siente más segura; un residente dijo que finalmente puede dormir tranquilo. El programa también ofrece opciones, como unirse al ejército nacional o aprender un oficio, según los requisitos.

**Próximo paso** – El programa DDR seguirá apoyando a más combatientes que entregan sus armas y se reintegran a la sociedad. Grupos locales e internacionales continuarán trabajando para asegurar una paz duradera y brindar formación y apoyo a los excombatientes.

articles.title: A Chinese Korean woman's story under the red flag
articles.summary: The story is about an ethnic minority woman from the Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture in China who withstood political upheaval, ethnic traditions, and rigid gender norms to survive.
articles.content:
The Cultural Revolution (1966–1976) disrupted schools, derailed careers, and reshaped countless lives across China. For many, it meant a lost decade of education. But for ethnic minority women like Lee YJ from the Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture in China’s northeast, a region at the border of China and North Korea, the challenges were more than political as they had to withstand political upheaval, ethnic traditions, and rigid gender norms to survive.

In May 2025, Global Voices’ contributor Jo Carter sat down with Lee, now in her late seventies, to hear her story. By recording her words, this project seeks not to romanticize or generalize, but to preserve one woman’s voice. Her account shows how political upheaval, gender, and ethnicity intertwined to shape the lives of ordinary Korean women in northeast China. It is part of a larger mosaic of voices that might otherwise fade with time.

Yanbian: “The Third Korea”

As Yanbian (depicted in red on the map to the right) lies directly across the river from the Korean peninsula, it has become a natural destination for Korean migrants seeking a new home in China. The history of migration stretches back centuries: as early as the mid-17th century, during the late Ming dynasty, groups of Koreans crossed the Tumen River into China, often fleeing natural disasters or famine. Later, in the early 20th century, Japan’s colonization of Korea (1910–1945) triggered another wave of refugees, many escaping persecution by the Japanese military. These Korean refugees had played a significant role in supporting the Korean Independence Movement.

The Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture was established in 1952, amid the Korean War (1950–1953), when a large number of Koreans in the region were recruited to join the Chinese People's Volunteer Army to support North Korea and suffered tremendous casualties. However, as the relationship between the People's Republic of China (PRC) and the Soviet Union turned sour during the Cultural Revolution, ethnic Koreans in Yanbian became targets of persecution because of their familial connections in pro-Soviet North Korea and pro-US South Korea.

Currently, about one in three people is of Korean descent in Yanbian, which is sometimes called the “Third Korea.”

Post-Korean War generation

Born into a poor family as the middle child of eight in the 1950s, Lee grew up in a household where girls were expected to work hard, endure hardship, and put family first:

When I was six years old, I was already taking care of three younger siblings. My friends were playing outside, jumping across the river, climbing trees, but I carried my baby sister on my back and held my brother’s hand. Another brother was following me like a shadow.

Her mother enforced strict discipline, demanding that Lee come home early and devote herself to childcare. Any delay was met with punishment — an early lesson in what it meant to be a daughter in a Korean household at the time.

Yet her mother’s severity reflected the norms of her generation, shaped by years of hardship, domestic violence, and the burden of raising eight children in poverty.

The burden of childcare delayed Lee’s education. She entered primary school two years later than her peers and soon fell ill from inadequate clothing in Yanbian’s bitter winters, missing yet another year.

When she finally settled into school, her talent was evident: she consistently ranked at the top of her class.

Education disrupted

By the end of junior high in 1966, she was chosen as one of the region’s outstanding students and invited to Tiananmen Square in the capital city, Beijing. There, she caught a glimpse of Mao Zedong waving from a passing car. “I was proud,” she recalled with a smile.

For a girl from a poor ethnic minority household in Yanbian to be chosen as one of the region’s outstanding students was extraordinary. Only the very best students from across China had the honor of representing the nation's future by standing in Tiananmen Square as Chairman Mao's followers. To catch even a fleeting glimpse of Mao Zedong from a passing car was, in that era, a once-in-a-lifetime moment. And for Lee, it was a moment of recognition for her efforts and talents, despite the difficult circumstances.

Lee’s dream of continuing her education ended abruptly in 1966, when the Cultural Revolution led to school closures nationwide. She was assigned to work in a local farm commune and later promoted to team head, helping to arrange the daily duties of other commune members.

She was married off through a match in 1973. Her husband, GR Park, came from a family with a harrowing past. Park’s father was born in northern Korea in 1910, when Japan officially colonized Korea through the Japan-Korea Treaty. Koreans fought back to liberate the country and were violently suppressed. Park had witnessed Japanese soldiers storm his village, and his entire family had been massacred. He alone survived, escaping with nothing but his life. Traumatized and orphaned, he fled across the border alone to China’s northeast. That trauma cast a long shadow over the next generation.

Lee’s husband struggled with alcohol, gambling, and a violent temper. But what was most corrosive was the constant belittling and gaslighting. Though she managed the household single-handedly, he would mock her as “stupid” and “ignorant.” At meals, he often lay sprawled at the table, barking single-word commands — “booze,” “rice,” “chopsticks.” His meager earnings disappeared into drink, leaving Lee to shoulder farm work and odd jobs to feed the family and raise two daughters alone.

Following the end of the Cultural Revolution in 1976, China began rebuilding its education system. In 1977, the government reinstated the National College Entrance Examination (高考/Gaokao), allowing universities to reopen their doors and invite new students to apply.

In her village, everyone believed Lee would easily pass the university entrance exams. She was known for her intelligence, leadership, and dedication — she even led the local women’s federation, where she organized communal work, offered support to struggling wives, and shared her knowledge of cooking and home remedies. Her kimchi became locally famous, a symbol of both skill and generosity.

But despite the opportunity, Lee couldn’t continue her education. “I had no one to look after my daughter,” she said.

Hope for the future generations

Lee’s daughters carried forward the academic dreams she could not fulfill. Both entered top Chinese universities and went on to become professors. Her granddaughters now pursue studies abroad, with plans to continue their education. She said:

I want my grandchild to do everything they want to do, with all their heart. I hope they can soar as high as possible.

For Lee, she is proud but not bitter. Her voice was calm, grounded in memory rather than regret. What she could not have, her daughters and granddaughters now pursue.

Her second daughter, MJ Choi, reflected on her mother’s life:

I saw my mother live with great strength and positivity, supporting both her family and the community. Her misfortune was simply being born into that era. The patriarchal culture of the Korean peninsula also hurt her and us as well. Watching my mother endure my father’s drinking and abuse made me believe that women’s suffering was a virtue. But now I want to cut off those harmful traditions. Being elevated simply for being a man is harmful not only for women but also for men. What I tell my daughters is that the most important thing is a relationship built on equality and mutual respect.

Lee’s story was not an exception — it was the reality faced by countless Korean women of her generation in Yanbian, and across China.

The gender inequalities that constrained her life have not vanished. Across East Asia today, the memory of women who were silenced, overburdened, or denied choices still shapes how younger women view family and marriage. For some, choosing to delay or even forgo marriage is not only personal but also a quiet rejection of the sacrifices that defined their mothers’ and grandmothers’ lives.

Her experiences illuminate how a talented girl, shaped by rigid gender roles, ethnic traditions, and political upheaval, lost her chance at education but still sustained her family and community. By sharing her words, we are reminded that history is not only written by leaders or events, but also by the quiet resilience of women whose voices deserve to be heard.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the inspiring resilience and strength of an ethnic minority woman overcoming political upheaval, gender inequality, and ethnic discrimination. It sheds light on broader issues of gender roles and ethnic minority struggles in China, emphasizing the importance of preserving marginalized voices and promoting equality. The story has significant social impact and meaningful scope as it reflects the experiences of many women in similar contexts and advocates for progress in gender equality and ethnic minority rights.
articles.personality_title: A Korean woman's journey through hardship and hope in northeast China
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Lee YJ is an ethnic Korean woman from Yanbian, a region in northeast China near North Korea. Born in the 1950s, she grew up during a time of political chaos called the Cultural Revolution, which disrupted education and daily life across China. For ethnic minorities like Lee, challenges included strict traditions and gender roles.

**What happened** – Lee was a bright student who earned a special honor to visit Beijing and see Mao Zedong. But when schools closed in 1966, her education stopped. She worked on a farm and later married a man with a difficult past. Despite facing hardship at home, including her husband's abuse, Lee cared for her family and led community efforts. Though she could not continue school, her daughters went on to attend top universities and became professors.

**Impact** – Lee’s story shows how political events, ethnic identity, and gender expectations shaped the lives of many Korean women in Yanbian. It reveals the strength needed to survive tough times and how one person’s experience connects to a larger history of minority voices often overlooked. Her life also highlights ongoing struggles with gender inequality in the region.

**What's next step** – By sharing stories like Lee’s, more people can understand the challenges faced by ethnic minority women. This awareness can encourage respect, support for equal rights, and efforts to preserve such histories. Lee’s family now hopes future generations will have more freedom to follow their dreams.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Lee’s life reveals how determination and family support helped overcome cultural and political barriers, inspiring future generations to pursue education and equality.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le parcours d'une femme coréenne face aux épreuves et à l’espoir dans le nord-est de la Chine
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Lee YJ est une femme coréenne ethnique originaire de Yanbian, une région du nord-est de la Chine proche de la Corée du Nord. Née dans les années 1950, elle a grandi pendant la Révolution culturelle, une période de chaos politique qui a perturbé l’éducation et la vie quotidienne en Chine. Pour les minorités ethniques comme Lee, les défis comprenaient des traditions strictes et des rôles de genre rigides.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lee était une élève brillante qui a reçu l’honneur spécial de visiter Pékin et de voir Mao Zedong. Mais lorsque les écoles ont fermé en 1966, sa scolarité s’est arrêtée. Elle a travaillé dans une ferme puis s’est mariée avec un homme au passé difficile. Malgré les difficultés à la maison, y compris les violences de son mari, Lee a pris soin de sa famille et a dirigé des actions communautaires. Bien qu’elle n’ait pas pu poursuivre ses études, ses filles ont fréquenté des universités prestigieuses et sont devenues professeures.

**Impact** – L’histoire de Lee montre comment les événements politiques, l’identité ethnique et les attentes liées au genre ont façonné la vie de nombreuses femmes coréennes à Yanbian. Elle révèle la force nécessaire pour survivre à des temps difficiles et comment l’expérience d’une personne s’inscrit dans une histoire plus large de voix minoritaires souvent oubliées. Sa vie met aussi en lumière les luttes persistantes pour l’égalité des genres dans la région.

**Prochaine étape** – En partageant des histoires comme celle de Lee, davantage de personnes peuvent comprendre les défis rencontrés par les femmes des minorités ethniques. Cette prise de conscience peut encourager le respect, le soutien aux droits égaux et la préservation de ces mémoires. La famille de Lee espère désormais que les futures générations pourront suivre leurs rêves plus librement.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La vie de Lee montre comment la détermination et le soutien familial ont permis de surmonter les barrières culturelles et politiques, inspirant les générations futures à poursuivre l’éducation et l’égalité.
articles.personality_title_es: El viaje de una mujer coreana entre dificultades y esperanza en el noreste de China
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Lee YJ es una mujer coreana étnica de Yanbian, una región en el noreste de China cerca de Corea del Norte. Nació en los años 50 y creció durante la Revolución Cultural, un periodo de caos político que interrumpió la educación y la vida diaria en China. Para las minorías étnicas como Lee, los retos incluían tradiciones estrictas y roles de género rígidos.

**Qué pasó** – Lee fue una estudiante destacada que recibió el honor especial de visitar Pekín y ver a Mao Zedong. Pero cuando cerraron las escuelas en 1966, su educación se detuvo. Trabajó en una granja y luego se casó con un hombre con un pasado difícil. A pesar de enfrentar dificultades en casa, incluyendo el abuso de su esposo, Lee cuidó de su familia y lideró esfuerzos comunitarios. Aunque no pudo continuar sus estudios, sus hijas ingresaron a universidades de primer nivel y se convirtieron en profesoras.

**Impacto** – La historia de Lee muestra cómo los eventos políticos, la identidad étnica y las expectativas de género moldearon la vida de muchas mujeres coreanas en Yanbian. Revela la fuerza necesaria para sobrevivir tiempos difíciles y cómo la experiencia de una persona se conecta con una historia más amplia de voces minoritarias a menudo ignoradas. Su vida también destaca las luchas continuas con la desigualdad de género en la región.

**Próximo paso** – Compartiendo historias como la de Lee, más personas pueden entender los desafíos que enfrentan las mujeres de minorías étnicas. Esta conciencia puede fomentar el respeto, el apoyo a los derechos iguales y la preservación de estas historias. La familia de Lee ahora espera que las futuras generaciones tengan más libertad para seguir sus sueños.

**Resumen en una frase** – La vida de Lee muestra cómo la determinación y el apoyo familiar ayudaron a superar barreras culturales y políticas, inspirando a las futuras generaciones a buscar la educación y la igualdad.
